Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a Power-Hardware-in-the-Loop (PHIL) System to Enhance Research and Student Research Training in Engineering and Computer Science

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract:
Nontechnical
This Major Research Instrumentation award will enable the acquisition of a state-of-the-art Power-Hardware-in-the-Loop system that is currently revolutionizing test engineering on many levels, including power/smart grids, vehicle and communication systems, civil structures, robotics, and aerospace. The acquisition of this highly scalable and configurable, computationally efficient simulation and experimental testing platform will enable the diverse multi-user community of engineers, computer scientists, and student researchers at San Francisco State University and San Jose State University to develop and evaluate complex systems and/or physical components in an integrated fashion. This system will significantly enhance the research capability at the two participating Hispanic-serving, non-Ph.D-granting institutions that rank among the leaders in ethnic diversity in the U.S. It will create well-equipped research environments that integrate research and research training and provide crucial research infrastructure needed to catalyze cross-disciplinary collaborations among faculty members and initiate and/or strengthen their collaborations with other research institutions and industrial partners. It will enrich the education of Hispanic, female, and African-American students by providing them hands-on research training in frontier technology. It will advance the careers of junior female faculty members enabling them to serve as role models for female students who remain underrepresented in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics. It will also lead to the creation of new teaching and research laboratories that will be integrated into the engineering and computer science curricula.
Technical
The Power-Hardware-in-the-Loop system will become an indispensable tool to stimulate new research in four key sectors of engineering and computer science research: vehicle system, power/smart grid, prosthetic robotic arm development, and structural analysis. In vehicle system research, it will be used to catalyze progress in the following areas: (1) improvements of the reliability, cost-effectiveness, and efficiency of key electric drive components in electrified vehicles; (2) development of hybrid energy storage systems to accelerate the introduction of electrified vehicles in the transportation sector; and (3) development of in-cylinder control strategies for advanced combustion modes in compression-ignition engines. In the power/smart grid research sector, it will be used to enhance research opportunities in the following areas: (1) investigation of the grid integration impacts of electric vehicle charging and renewable energy sources; (2) experimental evaluation of power electronic interfaces in smart grids; (3) failure analyses of power equipment in power grids; and (4) development of communication and/or smart sensing infrastructure in smart grids. The instrument will also enhance the computational capacity for high-fidelity simulation of analytical substructure and facilitate the developments of advanced control interfaces for the next-generation of myoelectric prosthetic robotic arms.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This Major Research Instrumentation award has enabled the acquisition of a state-of-the-art Power-Hardware-in-the-Loop (PHIL) system. This PHIL is currently used as a real-time simulation and experimental testing platform by the diverse multi-user community of engineers, computer scientists, and student researchers. The requested instrument has broad impacts on many levels. It has significantly enhanced the research capability of faculty and students by providing critical infrastructure.  It has also fostered interdisciplinary collaborations across many disciplines including electrical engineering, computer engineering and science and data science.  The PIs are active educators and have been committed to advance the research experiences for students, particularly underrepresented groups. We have provided these students access to top quality instrumentation and research-enriched learning experience that are instrumental for their future careers. For instance, the PHIL has equipped students with extensive skills for testing complex systems in the fields of electrical engineering, computer engineering and computer science. Such knowledge will help them to develop into highly skilled, successful engineers and scientists. Additionally, the PHIL has made significant impacts on both the undergraduate and graduate curricula.

The equipment has been used to stimulate new research and provide necessary simulation and experiment platforms in broad fields of electrical and computer engineering and computer science. We have built a variety of models in Power-Hardware-in-the-Loop (PHIL) to comprehensively validate our research, so the PHIL has been used to catalyze progress in broad fields. For vehicle system research, we have focused on developing rare-earth-free electric drive systems and vehicle cyber-physical security. We have developed advanced controls to improve performance of switched reluctance machines that show great promise in electric vehicles due to their rigidity, non-reliance on rare-earth permanent magnet materials, and extended-speed constant-power range. With the significant increase in vehicle-to-infrastructure/cloud/vehicle communications, connected electric vehicles are becoming vulnerable to a wide range of cyber-physical attacks that could potentially degrade the performance. With real-time vehicle PHIL testbed, we have opened a new line of research in cyber-physical security associated with electric vehicles.  We have proposed a generalized methodology to assess the vulnerability of electric vehicles due to cyber-attacks at the device and system levels. Specifically, we propose innovative index-based security criteria as well as a set of evaluation metrics for each electric drive system and the vehicle consisting of four electric drive systems. Additionally, we propose novel cyber-attack detection methods to enhance the cyber-physical security of the connected electric vehicle.

For smart grid research, we have focused on cyber-physical security and vehicle to grid integration. As the number of distributed energy resources increases, the power grid grows into distributed power electronics-based smart grids (PESG). Smart grid security, however, mostly focuses on the grid level and does not comprehensively study the cyber-physical attacks that cause component faults or the degradation of individual power electronics converters. To address the increasing security challenges, we have proposed a novel vulnerability assessment methodology for PESG, which considers the performance and stability of each inverter and the grid. We have also proposed a novel high-dimensional data-driven cyber-physical attack detection and identification approach based on the electric waveform data in distribution power girds. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first attempt to use raw electrical waveform data to detect and identify cyber-physical attacks that target power electronics. Further, we have proposed a deep- learning-based method to detect and diagnose cyber-attacks on DC/DC and DC/AC converters for PV systems with only one voltage sensor and one current sensor at the point of common coupling (PCC). Other relevant works include cyber-attack detection using  PMU data, a noncooperative game-theoretic framework to model the social welfare optimization problem with load aggregators participating in integrated economic dispatch and demand response, and an online distributed IoT security monitoring algorithm.
